definitions: instrument that measures and displays the speed of a vehicle
examples: The speedometer showed we were traveling at sixty miles per hour
His vintage car had a beautifully restored analog speedometer

definitions: oval track designed for motor racing competitions and events
highway designed for high-speed travel with limited access points
examples: The Indianapolis Motor Speedway hosts the famous Indy 500 race
Thousands of fans packed the speedway for the championship event
Traffic moved smoothly along the speedway during rush hour
The new speedway reduced travel time between the two cities

definitions: short period of time or particular type of weather
words believed to have magical power when spoken or written
brief period of particular weather, especially cold or hot
examples: She worked for a spell at the local bookstore
After a spell of silence, he finally spoke up
The witch cast a powerful spell on the prince
Ancient books contained spells for protection and healing
We're expecting a cold spell next week in January
The dry spell lasted for three months straight

definitions: person who spells words, especially in a particular way
book used for teaching spelling to students in school
examples: She was the best speller in her fifth-grade class
Poor spellers often struggle with written communication tasks
The old speller contained lists of commonly misspelled words
Teachers used the speller to prepare students for tests

definitions: way in which a word is spelled using letters
process or activity of writing or naming letters of words
examples: The spelling of 'receive' often confuses beginning writers
British and American spelling sometimes differ for certain words
Spelling was her strongest subject in elementary school
Daily spelling practice improved his writing skills significantly

definitions: person who spends money in a particular way or amount
examples: She was known as a careful spender who saved regularly
Big spenders kept the luxury retail market thriving downtown

definitions: act of paying out money for goods, services, or expenses
examples: Government spending on education increased by ten percent annually
Holiday spending reached record levels this December season

definitions: person who spends money carelessly, extravagantly, or wastefully without thought
examples: His spendthrift habits left him bankrupt within two years
The spendthrift heir squandered the entire family fortune quickly

definitions: male reproductive cell that fertilizes the female egg cell
waxy substance from sperm whale used historically in products
examples: Sperm must reach the egg for fertilization to occur
The fertility clinic analyzed his sperm count and motility
Sperm oil was once prized for lamp fuel and candles
The sperm whale gets its name from this waxy substance

definitions: perfectly round three-dimensional geometric shape like a ball
particular area of activity, interest, expertise, or influence
examples: The Earth is not a perfect sphere but slightly flattened
Crystal spheres decorated the chandelier in the grand ballroom
Her sphere of influence extended throughout the technology industry
Politics remained outside his sphere of interest or expertise

definitions: ancient Egyptian stone statue with human head and lion body
person who is mysterious, enigmatic, or difficult to understand
examples: The Great Sphinx of Giza guards the pyramid complex
Ancient sphinxes lined the entrance to the temple ruins
She remained a sphinx, revealing nothing about her past
The CEO was a sphinx when questioned about merger plans

definitions: aromatic plant substance used to flavor or season food
element that adds interest, excitement, or variety to something
examples: She added exotic spices to the curry dish recipe
The spice merchant sold cinnamon, nutmeg, and cardamom
Travel adds spice to life through new experiences daily
Their relationship needed more spice to stay interesting

definitions: eight-legged arachnid that spins webs to catch prey
long-handled skillet with legs used for cooking over coals
examples: The spider spun an intricate web in the corner
Most spiders are harmless and beneficial to gardens
She cooked cornbread in a cast iron spider pan
The camping spider sat perfectly over the hot coals

definitions: lengthy or extravagant speech or argument usually intended to persuade
examples: The salesman gave his usual spiel about product benefits
She listened patiently to his spiel about investment opportunities

definitions: thin pointed piece of metal, wood, or other material
sharp sudden increase in quantity, rate, or intensity of something
forceful downward hit in volleyball to score a point
examples: Railroad spikes held the tracks firmly to wooden ties
The fence was topped with metal spikes for security
The spike in gas prices affected everyone's monthly budget
Emergency rooms saw a spike in flu cases last winter
Her powerful spike won the match point for the team
The player jumped high to spike the ball over the net

definitions: accidental flow of liquid from its container onto surface
fall from a horse, bicycle, or other elevated position
examples: The oil spill devastated the coastal ecosystem for years
She quickly cleaned the coffee spill from her desk
He took a bad spill from his mountain bike yesterday
The jockey walked away uninjured from the dramatic spill

definitions: person who accidentally or carelessly spills liquids or materials
examples: The chronic spiller always needed extra napkins at dinner
Coffee spillers were banned from the computer lab area

definitions: overflow of liquid or material from one container to another
indirect effect or consequence spreading from one area to another
examples: The spillover from the dam flooded the valley below
Parking spillover from the concert filled neighborhood streets
Economic spillover from tourism benefited surrounding rural communities significantly
The conflict's spillover into neighboring countries concerned international observers

definitions: passage or channel for surplus water to flow over or around dam
examples: The spillway prevented the dam from overflowing during floods
Engineers inspected the concrete spillway for structural damage annually

definitions: rapid turning or whirling motion around a central axis
particular bias or slant given to information or news
short trip in a vehicle for pleasure or testing
examples: The washing machine's spin cycle removes excess water effectively
The figure skater's spin was perfectly controlled and graceful
Politicians put their own spin on the economic data
The media's spin on the story influenced public opinion
Let's take the new car for a spin this afternoon
They went for a spin along the coastal highway

definitions: dark green leafy vegetable high in iron and nutrients
examples: Fresh spinach makes a nutritious addition to any salad
The recipe called for two cups of chopped spinach leaves

definitions: injection of anesthetic into the spinal canal for medical procedures
examples: The patient received a spinal before the cesarean section surgery
The spinal provided complete numbness below the injection site

definitions: rod or pin that rotates or serves as an axis
device used for spinning fibers into thread or yarn
examples: The spindle on the lathe held the wood piece securely
Door knobs attach to the spindle that passes through doors
She used a drop spindle to spin wool into yarn
Ancient spindles were essential tools for textile production

definitions: series of vertebrae extending from skull to pelvis in vertebrates
edge of a book where pages are bound together
sharp rigid projection on plants or animals for protection
examples: The spine provides support and flexibility for the body
X-rays showed a slight curvature in her lower spine
The book's spine displayed the title and author's name
Library books often have damaged spines from heavy use
Cactus spines protect the plant from thirsty desert animals
The porcupine's spines stood erect when it felt threatened

definitions: device or toy that spins or rotates around axis
person who spins fibers into thread or yarn professionally
cricket bowler who imparts spin to the ball
examples: The fidget spinner became a popular toy among students
The game spinner pointed to different colored sections randomly
The spinner worked at the textile mill for twenty years
Traditional spinners still demonstrate their craft at festivals
The team's best spinner took five wickets in the match
Leg spinners and off spinners use different bowling techniques

definitions: act or process of rotating rapidly around an axis
process of drawing out and twisting fibers into thread
indoor cycling exercise class with stationary bikes and music
examples: The spinning of the earth creates day and night cycles
Her head was spinning after the amusement park ride
Spinning cotton into thread was once done entirely by hand
The spinning wheel revolutionized textile production in medieval times
She attends spinning class three times a week for cardio
The spinning instructor motivated everyone with energetic music playlist

definitions: older woman who has never married, especially one past typical marrying age
examples: Victorian novels often featured spinster aunts as secondary characters
The term spinster appears on legal documents in some jurisdictions

definitions: curve that winds around a center point getting progressively closer or farther
continuous and accelerating increase or decrease in something
examples: The staircase formed an elegant spiral up the tower
Snail shells display a perfect logarithmic spiral pattern
Inflation caused a wage-price spiral throughout the economy
The team entered a downward spiral after losing key players

definitions: tall pointed structure on top of a building, especially a church
examples: The cathedral's spire rose two hundred feet above the city
Lightning struck the church spire during the violent storm

definitions: non-physical part of a person regarded as their true self
supernatural being or ghost of a dead person
strong distilled alcoholic beverage such as whiskey or vodka
prevailing mood, attitude, or feeling of enthusiasm and energy
examples: Many believe the spirit survives after the body dies
Her spirit remained unbroken despite the difficult circumstances
The old mansion was haunted by restless spirits at night
They claimed to communicate with spirits through the séance
The bar served premium spirits and craft cocktails exclusively
Grain spirits are distilled to a very high proof
The team showed great spirit in their comeback victory
School spirit was high during homecoming week festivities

definitions: religious song originating from African American Christian worship traditions
examples: The choir sang traditional spirituals at the church service
Spirituals like 'Swing Low, Sweet Chariot' have enduring cultural significance

definitions: belief that spirits of the dead can communicate with the living
examples: Spiritualism gained popularity in the nineteenth century after the Fox sisters
Modern spiritualism includes practices like mediumship and séances

definitions: person who believes spirits of the dead communicate with living
person who claims to communicate with spirits professionally
examples: The spiritualist movement attracted many followers in Victorian England
Spiritualists gathered weekly to attempt contact with deceased relatives
The famous spiritualist conducted séances for wealthy clients regularly
Many spiritualists claimed to channel messages from the other side

definitions: quality of being concerned with the human spirit or soul rather than material things
examples: Her spirituality deepened through years of meditation and reflection
Many people explore spirituality outside of organized religious institutions

definitions: saliva or liquid ejected from the mouth
metal rod for roasting meat over fire or heat source
narrow point of land projecting into water body
examples: The baby's spit stained the new shirt during feeding
The llama's spit can travel several feet when agitated
The whole pig roasted slowly on the spit over coals
They turned the spit regularly to cook the meat evenly
The lighthouse stood at the end of the sandy spit
Fishing was excellent from the rocky spit at low tide

definitions: desire to hurt, annoy, or offend someone out of petty malice
examples: She refused the invitation out of pure spite toward him
His actions were motivated by spite rather than reason

definitions: person with a fierce temper who speaks or acts impulsively
British single-seat fighter aircraft used in World War II
examples: His grandmother was a spitfire who never backed down from anyone
The young actress played the role of a feisty spitfire perfectly
The Spitfire became an icon of British resistance during the war
Restored Spitfires still fly at airshows around the world today

definitions: act of forcefully ejecting saliva or liquid from the mouth
examples: Spitting on the sidewalk is considered rude and unsanitary
The camel's spitting behavior is actually regurgitated stomach contents

definitions: scattering of water or liquid caused by impact
bright patch of color or light that attracts attention
small quantity of liquid added to a drink
examples: The splash from the diving board soaked nearby sunbathers
Children love making a big splash in the swimming pool
The splash of red paint brightened the monochrome room design
Her dress made quite a splash at the formal gala
Add just a splash of cream to the coffee mixture
He ordered whiskey with a splash of soda water

definitions: landing of a spacecraft in the ocean after a mission
examples: The Apollo capsule's splashdown occurred in the Pacific Ocean
Navy ships waited at the splashdown site for spacecraft recovery

definitions: act of causing water to scatter and make noise through movement
examples: The splashing in the pool could be heard from inside
Splashing through puddles delighted the children after the rainstorm

definitions: scattered drops or spots of liquid or semi-liquid substance
random pattern created by thrown or spilled liquid material
examples: Paint splatter covered the artist's studio floor and walls
The splatter of grease required immediate kitchen cleanup
The splatter pattern helped forensic investigators reconstruct the crime
Jackson Pollock's splatter paintings revolutionized modern abstract art

definitions: organ that filters blood and produces white blood cells
bad temper or spite, especially when vented in words
examples: The spleen helps filter old red blood cells from circulation
His enlarged spleen required immediate medical attention and monitoring
He vented his spleen against the government's new policies
Her spleen was evident in every bitter word she spoke

definitions: magnificent and splendid appearance, grandeur, or display of wealth
examples: The palace ballroom was decorated in full splendor for the gala
Autumn's splendor painted the mountains in brilliant colors

definitions: magnificent and splendid appearance, grandeur, or display of wealth
examples: The splendour of the royal wedding captivated millions worldwide
Natural splendour surrounded the mountain lodge on all sides

definitions: joint made by overlapping and binding two ends together
examples: The electrician made a secure splice in the damaged wire
Film editors used to splice movie reels together by hand

definitions: process of joining rope, wire, film, or genetic material together
examples: Gene splicing allows scientists to modify organism DNA sequences
Rope splicing creates strong permanent connections between rope sections

definitions: rigid support used to immobilize broken or injured body part
examples: The doctor applied a splint to her broken finger immediately
Temporary splints can be made from magazines in emergencies

definitions: small thin sharp piece of wood, glass, or similar material
small group that breaks away from a larger organization
examples: She carefully removed the splinter from her child's finger
Tiny splinters of glass covered the accident scene area
The splinter group formed their own political party last year
Several splinter factions emerged after the organization's leadership crisis

definitions: division or separation into two or more parts
crack, tear, or fissure in something, especially lengthwise
gymnastics position with legs extended in opposite directions
examples: The split in the party weakened their election chances significantly
They agreed on an even split of the lottery winnings
The split in the wood ran along the entire length
A deep split appeared in the ice during spring thaw
She performed a perfect split during her floor routine
Dancers practice splits daily to maintain their flexibility
